title: 106_s1501
content:
The Motor Carrier Safety Improvement Act of 1999 establishes a Motor Carrier Safety Administration. The Motor Carrier Safety Administration is established as an administration of the Department of Transportation. The Administrator, appointed by the President with Senate approval, must have professional experience in motor carrier safety and reports directly to the Secretary. The Administrator is responsible for carrying out duties, powers, and functions related to motor carrier safety as prescribed by the Secretary. Within the Motor Carrier Safety Administration, there is a separate division for overseeing commercial motor coach safety and carrying out functions prescribed by the Secretary. The Administrator is responsible for all motor carrier safety functions previously handled by the Office of Motor Carrier and Highway Safety. The Office of Motor Carrier and Highway Safety functions and personnel are transferred to the Administrator within the Motor Carrier Safety Administration. Unexpended balances of funds are also transferred. Personnel and funding are capped at the FY 2000 level, unless specified otherwise in the Motor Carrier Safety Improvement Act of 1999. The Motor Carrier Safety Administration personnel and funds are limited to the levels of the Department of Transportation for fiscal year 2000. Conforming amendments are made to the Federal Highway Administration. The chapter analysis for the subsection is amended by adding new information at the end. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. The Motor Carrier Safety Administration is authorized to receive funds from the Highway Trust Fund for operating expenses. The Secretary of Transportation can use specified amounts for State grants, with a minimum allocation from the Highway Trust Fund. The Highway Trust Fund will provide not less than $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, and $110,000,000 for fiscal year 2003 for information systems funding. The funding for information systems is authorized as follows:
- $35,000,000 for fiscal year 2000
- $36,500,000 for fiscal year 2001
- $36,500,000 for fiscal year 2002
- $39,500,000 for fiscal year 2003 The Secretary may provide emergency grants of up to $1,000,000 to States at risk of failing compliance requirements for commercial driver's license programs. If a State fails to comply after receiving the grant, the Secretary will suspend its authority to issue commercial driver's licenses. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE IMPROVEMENTS: The Secretary of Transportation must implement safety improvement recommendations from the Department of Transportation Inspector General's Report. Progress must be reported to relevant committees every 90 days until all recommendations are implemented.

SEC. 5. IMPROVEMENTS TO THE COMMERCIAL DRIVERS LICENSE PROGRAM. In section 31311(a) of title 49, United States Code, amendments are made regarding commercial driver's licenses. Changes include recording violations that result in disqualification and prohibiting the issuance of special licenses to individuals with commercial driver's licenses. The State must maintain a record of violations and convictions for individuals with commercial driver's licenses, and may not disclose certain information as per section 31310 of the code. The text discusses amendments to regulations regarding the withholding of information from the record of commercial driver's license holders, as well as the initiation of a rulemaking for a Federal medical qualification certificate to be included in commercial driver's licenses. The text discusses the establishment of a national registry of preferred medical providers for commercial drivers, requiring providers to demonstrate knowledge of safety standards. Additionally, it introduces decertification authority for states in substantial noncompliance with regulations, prohibiting them from licensing procedures and issuing commercial driver's licenses until compliance is met. The text introduces a national registry of preferred medical providers for commercial drivers and grants decertification authority to states not complying with regulations. SEC. 6 introduces improved data collection and motor carrier safety measures. The Secretary of Transportation will implement a program with states to enhance data collection and analysis on commercial motor vehicle crashes. The program will be administered by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in collaboration with the Motor Carrier Safety Administration. Data will be collected electronically and training will be provided to ensure data quality and uniformity. The collected data, including driver citation and conviction information, will be integrated for analysis. The Secretary of Transportation will transmit a report to Congress within 3 years on the improved data program for commercial motor vehicle crashes. Up to $10,000,000 may be used for funding from 2001 to 2003. The Secretary will also work with states to harmonize reporting violations. The Secretary of Transportation, in collaboration with states, will develop a uniform system for electronic data transmission on violations of motor vehicle laws by commercial drivers. A report on the implementation progress must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Additionally, the Secretary will establish privacy protection policies for electronic recorders used to monitor vehicles and operators. The Secretary of Transportation will establish privacy protection policies for electronic recorders used to monitor vehicle and operator performance. Regulations for commercial motor vehicles will apply to operators of 8-passenger vehicles, with data improvements for uniform carrier registration. Data improvements for uniform carrier registration system and minimum financial responsibility regulations are being amended under the Motor Carrier Safety Improvement Act of 1999. The uniform carrier registration system must be operational within one year of the Act's enactment. Minimum financial responsibility requirements for transportation of passengers are also being updated. The Secretary will require all individuals subject to minimum financial responsibility regulations to provide evidence of the required financial responsibility. The Secretary of Transportation may establish a Commercial Motor Vehicle Safety Advisory Committee to provide advice on regulatory issues. The committee's members will be appointed from various affected groups, and it will assist in the timely completion of rulemakings. The Secretary of Transportation may establish a Commercial Motor Vehicle Safety Advisory Committee to provide advice on regulatory issues, with members appointed from various affected groups to assist in rulemaking completion. Additionally, Section 305 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to ensure accountability in owner-controlled insurance programs for transportation projects receiving Federal funding. This includes limits on reserves based on current and projected liabilities, adjustments in premiums and reserves, and discounted value considerations for future liabilities. The Secretary of Transportation may establish a Commercial Motor Vehicle Safety Advisory Committee for regulatory advice. Section 305 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to ensure accountability in owner-controlled insurance programs for transportation projects receiving Federal funding, with limits on reserves and refunds exceeding liabilities returned to the Federal government.
